intro: Valerianella hamata, commonly known as the hairy valerian, is a small annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 10–30 centimeters and is characterized by its hairy stems and small, clustered flowers. The leaves are ovate to lanceolate in shape and are often covered in fine hairs, giving the plant its common name. It blooms from June to August, producing tiny, pinkish-white flowers that attract pollinators like bees and flies. This plant prefers moist, well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and fields.
